en.av_c1: Consider the base case of a single infinite line in the plane. This line splits the plane into two regions.
en.av_c2: One region can be colored black and the other white to get a valid two-coloring.
en.av_c3: The induction hypothesis is that the set of regions formed by $n-1$ infinite lines can be two-colored.
en.av_c4: To prove the theorem for n, consider the set of regions formed by the $n-1$ lines remaining when any one of the $n$ lines is removed. For our example, assume that $n = 4$.
en.av_c5: So after we remove one, we now have 3 infinite lines.
en.av_c6: By the induction hypothesis, this set of regions can be two-colored.
en.av_c8: This splits the plane into two half-planes, each of which (independently) has a valid two-coloring inherited from the two-coloring of the plane with $n-1$ lines.
en.av_c9: Unfortunately, the regions newly split by the $n^{th}$ line violate the rule for a two-coloring.
en.av_c10: Let's take all regions on one side of the $n^{th}$ line (say half plane 2) and reverse their coloring. After doing so, this half-plane is still two-colored.
en.av_c11: Those regions split by the $n^{th}$ line are now properly two-colored, because the part of the region to one side of the line is now black and the region to the other side is now white.
en.av_c12: Thus, by mathematical induction, the entire plane is two-colored.
